subsection.name: 3.5 Cross-Database Issues
subsection.p: JDBC specification was created by Sun to provide a uniform way of connecting to relational databases from the Java code. In theory this should allow Java developer to create database-aware code that is portable across RDBMS vendors. In reality this is only partially true. While providing universal connectivity, JDBC doesn't handle certain portability issues. The following problems remain when developing with JDBC:

ul.li: There is no fully standard-compliant databases (even though all of them claim to be). Certain "standard" features may not be implemented in some RDBMS.
SQL syntax may vary across RDBMS. Things like outer join queries, database objects creation, BLOB handling, etc. are handled differently by different vendors.
Vendors provide their own extensions of SQL and JDBC functionality. Taking advantage of these extensions and creating portable code at the same time is not a trivial task.

subsection.p: This becomes even a bigger problem in a generic product like Cayenne that should support any database. Therefore Cayenne provides DbAdapter architecture as a way of handling database differences. It works in conjunction with JDBC.
